title: An Exploration of ECAPA-TDNN and x-vector Speaker Representations in Zero-shot Multi-speaker TTS
author: Marie Kunešová (NTIS Research Centre), Zdenek Hanzlíček (NTIS Research Centre), Jindřich Matoušek (NTIS Research Centre), ...
relevance_why: The paper provides insights into speaker embedding methods that can enhance text-to-speech systems, which may inform Haohe Liu's research in audio generation and restoration.
background: This study evaluates different speaker embedding techniques for synthesizing speech in the voices of unseen speakers, testing their effectiveness in a zero-shot text-to-speech setting.
contribution: This paper introduces a comparative analysis of three speaker encoders—H/ASP, x-vector, and ECAPA-TDNN—evaluating their performance in synthesizing speech across 24 target speakers.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Earlier studies mostly focused on embedding methods for speaker recognition and did not directly assess their implications for zero-shot text-to-speech synthesis.
technical_comparison.novelty: This research isolates the influence of speaker encoders on TTS performance while maintaining a consistent TTS framework.

key_innovation: The study provides empirical evidence on the effectiveness of traditional and state-of-the-art speaker embeddings, highlighting that the original H/ASP outperforms newer approaches in a TTS context.
real_world_impact: The findings can guide the development of more effective TTS systems, potentially improving voice synthesis applications in areas like virtual assistants, gaming, and media accessibility.
limitations: The study does not explore any encoder beyond those tested and may assume the results applicable exclusively to the Czech language.

new_terms.zero-shot TTS: **Zero-shot text-to-speech (TTS)** refers to the ability of a speech synthesis system to create speech for speakers it has not previously learned about, using minimal input data.
new_terms.speaker embedding: **Speaker embedding** is a vector representation of a speaker's voice characteristics used in speaker recognition and synthesis tasks.
